author: mklement0
body:
# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
# Define a simple (non-advanced) function with comment-based help.
function foo {
# .SYNOPSIS
# Hiya
}

Get-Help foo
```

Similarly, if you use `Get-Help` with `-Full` or `-Detailed`, the following inapplicable paragraph is shown:

```none
PARAMETERS
    <CommonParameters>
        This cmdlet supports the common parameters: Verbose, Debug,
        ErrorAction, ErrorVariable, WarningAction, WarningVariable,
        OutBuffer, PipelineVariable, and OutVariable. For more information, see
        about_CommonParameters (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113216).
```

# Expected behavior

```none
...
SYNTAX
    foo 
...
```

# Actual behavior

```none
...
SYNTAX
    foo [<CommonParameters>]
...
```

That is, the syntax diagram mistakenly suggests that `foo` is an advanced function.

# Environment data

```none
PowerShell Core 7.1.0-preview.5   # originally reported for: PowerShell Core v6.2.0-preview.3 
```

Interesting, @ChrSchultz, I still see the problem in RC1, both on Windows 10 (64-bit; Version 1809, OS Build: 17763.379) and on macOS 10.14.3

Just to rule out other factors: Do you get the same result when you run your `pwsh` instance with `-noprofile`?

title: Get-Help misrepresents non-advanced functions as advanced ones when comment-based help is present
